description.narrative: Strengthened leadership and technical capacities of the Office of the Ombudsman to deliver on their human rights mandates effectively
Other General Services - support to civil society
1. Percentage of human rights violation cases completed 2. No. of districts with community outreach structures

comment.narrative: 1. 35% of human rights violation cases completed 2. 4 districts with community outreach structures.

1. 199 cases on administrative malpractices. A total of 68 cases were concluded and recommended for closure representing a 34% conclusion rate. The OoO also carried out Training Workshops on Administrative Justice with the aim of reinforcing good Administrative Practices in Public Offices. 2. 4 districts with community outreach structures and Negotiated with National Civic Education Trust to act as satellite offices for collecting cases. During the period, the office also commenced awareness campaigns targeting Area Development Committees and Village Development Committee
1. 50% of human rights violation cases completed 2. 4 districts with community outreach structures.
1. 44% 2. 28 districts (Office of the ombudsman has signed MOUs and are working with NICE in all 28 districts)

comment.narrative: 1. 55% 2. 52% of the rejected and pended recommendations accepted. 3. 1 state party report completed and defended. Malawi became the first country to comply with the 2009 guidelines through timely submission of a combined report on the African Charter on Human and People’s Rights and the Protocol to the African Charter on Human and People’s Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa

description.narrative: 1. Number of policies, plans and planning instruments mainstreaming Disaster Risk Management (DRM) and early recovery. 2. Number of data and information tools developed and operational to enhance decision making on Disaster Risk Management 3. Number of coordination mechanisms developed, functional and strengthened on Disaster Risk Management

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 0 (inventory not available at design stage) 3. 15 (Disaster relief and rehabilitation committee and district civil protection committees functional in 14 districts)
1. 14 policies, plans and planning instruments mainstreaming Disaster Risk Management (DRM) and early recovery 2. 6 3. 30

1. 13 (in 2015 4 district development plans mainstreaming DRM, first ever DRM Policy approved, Budget Guidelines to maintream environment, climate change and DRM developed). Following the worst floods in the history of Malawi, early recovery programmes have been implemented with support from the Crisis Response unit. 2. 6 (Radio programme on DRM introduced, 2 climate information centres functional and sending out early warning information, small grants programme piloted in Malawi with guidelines developed, hazard and vulnerability maps developed for 15 disaster prone districts). 3. 28 (6 additional civil protection committees strengthened at village and area level)
1. 17 policies, plans and planning instruments mainstreaming Disaster Risk Management (DRM) and early recovery. 2. 16 3. 41

1. 15 (in 2017;DRM Policy, Climate Change Management Policy, National Agriculture Policy, early recovery supported). National Resilience Plan drafted awaiting approval, and DRM bill awaiting enactment. 2. 15 (Community maps done for 2 districts, mechanisms for community based flood risk management developed, 6 additional small grants with UNDP-china co financing implemented) 3. 37 (data collection tools after emergencies revised and translated in two local languages, evacuation plans developed for 6 districts and mapping for preparedness actions done to inform the contingency planning process.

Strengthened capacity of the Malawi Bureau of Standards to deliver business services and to achieve financial sustainability

participating-org.narrative: UN DEPT OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS

description.narrative: independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Enhance the ability to export goods from Malawi by reducing the need for re-testing, re-inspection, re-certification abroad through acceptance of measurements, tests, conformity assessment results issued in Malawi.

description.narrative: independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

- Number of National Quality Policies (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - Number of National Quality Strategies developed and approved for implementation - Number of standards accreditations granted to Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) by the International accreditation body - Number of Metrology Institutes constructed - Number of affirmative measures to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Number of SME able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets.

comment.narrative: - 0 National Quality Policies (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 0 National Quality Strategies developed and approved for implementation - 0 standards accreditations granted to Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) by the International accreditation body - 0 Metrology Institutes constructed - 0 affirmative measures to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - 0 Small and Medium Enterprises able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets

- 1 National Quality Policy (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 1 National Quality Strategy developed and approved for implementation - Preparatory steps and initiatives for Malawi Bureau of Standards to move towards being granted accreditation standards in the pilot accreditation phase by the International accreditation body undertaken - Initial construction works of the new MBS building to house offices and state of the art laboratories and equipment to supplement accreditation efforts started - 1 affirmative measure to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Recruitment of Small and Medium Enterprises to receive technical assistance to be able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets

- 1 National Quality Policy (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 1 National Quality Strategy developed and approved for implementation - Under the pilot accreditation phase, both in-country and out-of-country specialised capacity building initiatives for the Malawi Bureau of Standards for ISO/IEC 17021 and ISO/IEC 17065 and ISO/IEC 17025 have been undertaken in 2015 including purchase of specialised equipment - Construction of the new MBS complex to house offices and state of the art laboratories and equipment to supplement accreditation efforts has not started except the ground breaking ceremony - 1 affirmative measure to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Seven Small and Medium Enterprises have been recruited in Cohort 1 to get technical assistance so that they are able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets. Assessment of Cohort 2 SMEs has been done pending finalisation of actual recruitment. Technical support will be provided on Food Safety Management system; and Quality Management System.

- 1 National Quality Policy (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 1 National Quality Strategy developed and approved for implementation - Preparatory steps and initiatives for Malawi Bureau of Standards to move towards being granted accreditation standards in the pilot accreditation phase by the International accreditation body undertaken - Initial construction works of the new MBS building to house offices and state of the art laboratories and equipment to supplement accreditation efforts started - 1 affirmative measure to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Recruitment of Small and Medium Enterprises to receive technical assistance to be able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets

- 1 National Quality Policy was approved by Cabinet. - 1 National Quality Strategy was developed and approved for implementation - Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) was pre-assessed for accreditation of ISO 17021, ISO 17065 and ISO 17025. The assessors identifieed the risks and gaps to be addressed before formal accreditation requested is sought. - Construction works of the new MBS building to house offices and state of the art laboratories and equipment to supplement accreditation efforts commenced with about 25% of the work done - 1 affirmative measure in the form of a Strategic Plan is being developed to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards -Seven Small and Medium Enterprises continued to receive technical assistance

description.narrative: 1. Number of planning instruments on climate change and planning documents produced at national level district level. 2. Number of information and knowledge products on climate change produced. 3. Number of functional coordination mechanisms established and sustained. 4. Number of planning instruments for investment in climate change produced.

comment.narrative: 1. Climate change not mainstreamed in policies, development plans and programmes. 2. Data and knowledge on the impacts of climate change not accessible to the public. 3. Weak coordination mechanisms and implementation arrangements for climate change. 4. No plan for investment in climate change at national district level.

1. 12 (8 National; 5 District) 2. 21 (7 climate information centres; 4 learning products for the primary and education sectors, 10 mass media programmes) 3. 5 coordination mechanisms fully functional. 4. 2 (roll out the climate change investment plan to investors and develop foundational work for development of a climate change fund)

1. 12 (Climate policy approved by cabinet committee; Meteorology Policy drafted; National Adaptation Plan road map drafted stocktaking underway; ME Framework for climate change, revised National Adaptation Programmes of Action, National Climate Change Response Framework and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions launched, 4 district development plans mainstreamed climate change). 2. 18 (4 learning products for primary and secondary school sectors on climate change developed and used by the education sector; 4 climate information centres functional, 10 mass media and outreach programmes implemented). 3. 5 (technical, steering, Development Partners coordination group on climate change, GIS expert group and REDD Plus expert group established and fully functional). 4. 1

1. 5 (3 national; 2 district) 2. 1 comprehensive training manual on climate change targeting all secondary schools. 3. Troika on Environment, Climate Change and Natural Resource Management meets quarterly to guide joint action of GoM and its Development Partners. 4. Formulation of national fund for climate change and environment, modelled on Rwanda.

1. 1 National (National Climate Change Management Policy launched and under implementation; 0 district) 2. Sourcebook on Climate Change for secondary education completed and mainstreamed in the curriculum, including teacher instruction manual, 2 Climate Information Centres fully functional. 3. Troika for climate change well established, meets regularly. 4. Country Programme for Green Climate Fund (GCF) and roadmap for formulation of national climate fund initiated during reporting period.

- 1 Industrial Policy for Malawi developed and approved by Cabinet - 1 Trade Policy for Malawi developed and approved by Cabinet - 1 Sector Working Group through the conduit of the National Export Strategy operationalized - The Buy Malawi Campaign Strategy reviewed and revised strategy developed

- 1 Industrial Policy for Malawi developed and finalized and submitted to Cabinet pending approval - 1 Trade Policy for Malawi has been developed and finalized and submitted to Cabinet pending approval - 1 Sector Working Groups through the conduit of the National Export Strategy operationalized - The old Buy Malawi Campaign Strategy has been reviewed and the revised one has been finalised. The revised strategy seeks to encourage the public in Malawi to preferentially buy Malawian products, and with that shall foster accelerated production in and expansion of Malawian companies, leading to job creation, export and substantive economic growth,

- 1 Industrial Policy for Malawi developed and approved by Cabinet - 1 Trade Policy for Malawi developed and approved by Cabinet - 1 Sector Working Group through the conduit of the National Export Strategy operationalized - The Buy Malawi Campaign Strategy reviewed and revised strategy developed and launched for implementation and the Marketing Plan developed - The Export Processing Zone (EPZ) regulations reviewed

description.narrative: To strengthen the weather climate and hydrological monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to extreme weather and planning adaptation to climate change in Malawi

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard Annex 12
2 Domestic finance committed to DoDMA DCCMS and DWR to monitor extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 72 across men and women Annex 12
2 Annual budget of USD allocated to DoDMA DCCMS and DWR

1 CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 121 for both men and women Annex 12
2gt20 increase in domestic financing committed to DoDMA DCCMS and DWR to monitor extreme weather and climate change including equipment operation and maintenance

Considerable progress has been registered towards the attainment of objectives Despite the fact that the actual implementation of the project started in 2014 with a lengthy procurement process most of the hydrological and meteorological equipment has been purchased and delivered as well as installation in selected sites is ongoing Capacity building is also on track as a significant technical personnel from key institutions has received training thanks to the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services DCCMS and the Disaster Risk Management DoDMA who organised nine training courses ranging from 1 week to 24 months A list of the afforded capacity building initiatives has been uploaded for referencing
In relation to the set targets the baseline and the two indicators there was minimal quantifiable progress This reporting period was mainly dedicated to preparatory activities

Access to early warning information was enabled through awareness creation exercises that were conducted at district level 350 members of the Villages Civil Protection Committees VCPC received training on the benefits of early warning systems and the role that communities can play in disaster risk management
The national disaster management frameworks have been enhanced the National Disaster Management Policy has been approved by the Government of Malawi and dissemination at national level has been conducted Preparations for districtlevel dissemination are underway

There is considerable progress made towards the attainment of this outcome The installation of the early warning infrastructure is underway as ten automated weather stations have been procured and installed in six out of seven districts 86 coverage of the project area which constitutes at least 9 of national coverage Data from the AWS is being generated on an hourly basis Hydrological equipment has been procured but not yet installed Once installed it is expected that it will contribute to at least 6 of national coverage Modest progress has been registered that can be measured based on the indicators During the reporting period in question the focus was on preparatory activities
